Home

Welcome to the R programming workshops for Pharmaceutical Science and Chemistry

This set of workshops will guide you from the basics of R to data analysis relevant to your field. These will support you throughout your time at Kingston University and will also provide you with an invaluable future skill.

Workshops

Workshop Title Skills Learned
1 R You Ready? Getting Started with Chemistry Data! Introduction to R Basic syntax Simple plotting
2 Data in a Lab Coat: Cleaning and Wrangling Your Chemistry Data Importing data using readr
Data cleaning and manipulation using dplyr
3 Plotting Power! Visualizing Your Data Like a Pro Complex visualizations for scientific data Advanced ggplot2 visualizations
4 Make It Match! The Magic of Correlation and Regression Performing correlation and linear regression analysis
5 Tox Talk: Exploring Toxicity Data with Statistics Introduction to using R for statistical tests for comparing groups (e.g., t-tests, ANOVA)
6 Statistics Are Sexy: Hypothesis Testing and p values Introduction to the use of R for hypothesis testing and interpreting p-values
7 It’s All About the Data: Big Data in Chemistry Introduction to big data analysis using R
8 Chemical Reactions and Functions: R-ing the Curve! Applying functions and curve fitting to real-world chemical data
9 The Plot Thickens: Beautiful Data Visualization Advanced ggplot2 techniques for data visualization
10 Statistical Sherlock: Investigating Toxicity with Statistics Conducting statistical hypothesis testing to compare experimental groups

Examples where R is used in Chemistry & Pharmaceutical Science

The following is a collection of journal articles (links to!) where R has been critical in pushing forwards the boundaries of science in the following contexts (this list will be extended as we go on!):

Analytical Chemistry

  • Exploratory multivariate analysis using R Language for method development in liquid chromatography | Analytical and Bioanalytical Chemistry (https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00216-024-05705-y?)

  • Utilizing High-Resolution Mass Spectrometry Data Mining Strategy in R Programming Language for Rapid Annotation of Absorbed Prototypes and Metabolites of Gypenosides | Molecules (https://www.mdpi.com/1420-3049/30/4/779)

Medicinal Chemistry

  • The Use of the R Language for Medicinal Chemistry Applications | Bentham Science (https://www.eurekaselect.com/article/48427)

Pharmacokinetics

  • Design Evaluation and Optimization of Population Pharmacokinetics Model Using an R Package PopED (https://www.mdpi.com/2227-7390/11/21/4407)

  • Enabling transparent toxicokinetic modeling for public health risk assessment | PLOS One (https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0321321)

Formulations

  • AI-Driven Pharmaceutical Data Analysis Tool for Drug Formulation Development | Journal of Pharmaceutical Innovation (https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12247-025-10203-4)

Useful R packages

  • tidyverse
    Purpose: Data manipulation, cleaning, and visualization (includes dplyr, tidyr, ggplot2).
  • ggplot2
    Purpose: Grammar of graphics for high-quality plots of chemical and pharmaceutical data.
  • plotly
    Purpose: Interactive visualization for complex datasets.
  • shiny
    Purpose: Building interactive web apps for chemical data dashboards.
  • readr
    Purpose: Fast and friendly functions for reading rectangular data (CSV, TSV)

  • readxl
    Purpose: Import Excel files without external dependencies.

  • tidyr
    Purpose: Reshape messy data into tidy format (long vs wide).

  • dplyr
    Purpose: Grammar of data manipulation (filter, select, mutate, summarise).
